metadata.purpose: Define step-by-step validation process for all changes

critical-notice.requirement: Every piece of information must be validated. Every change must be verified. Every claim must be supported.

validation-philosophy.principle: Validation is not optional. It's the difference between reliable software and dangerous hallucinations.

phase.name: Pre-Validation
phase.description: Before making any change or claim

dual-explanation.technical: Pre-validation planning prevents downstream validation failures and optimizes resource allocation
dual-explanation.simple: Like checking your map and planning your route before starting a road trip

steps.step: Expand search if needed (up to 10 sources)

dual-explanation.technical: Multi-source validation reduces bias and improves confidence through triangulation
dual-explanation.simple: Like asking several experts instead of just one person for important advice

dual-explanation.technical: Cross-validation identifies consensus patterns while accounting for source reliability
dual-explanation.simple: Like checking if multiple weather services agree before planning an outdoor event

dual-explanation.technical: Runtime validation ensures theoretical knowledge translates to actual system behavior
dual-explanation.simple: Like testing your recipe while cooking instead of waiting until the end

dual-explanation.technical: Post-implementation validation provides final confirmation and creates audit trail
dual-explanation.simple: Like doing a final check that everything works correctly before shipping

type.name: Technical Specifications
type.sources: - Official docs (primary) - GitHub repositories - Stack Overflow (secondary) - Technical blogs (tertiary)

dual-explanation.technical: Technical specifications require high confidence due to system reliability dependencies
dual-explanation.simple: Like double-checking the measurements when building something that needs to fit exactly

type.name: API Information
type.sources: - API documentation - Changelog/release notes - API status page - Direct testing

dual-explanation.technical: API validation requires highest confidence due to integration failures and cost implications
dual-explanation.simple: Like testing if a key works in the lock before relying on it for security

type.name: Best Practices
type.sources: - Industry publications - Expert blogs - Conference talks - Academic papers

dual-explanation.technical: Best practices evolve with technology, requiring recent validation and context assessment
dual-explanation.simple: Like checking if cooking techniques are still recommended before following old recipes

type.name: Performance Claims
type.sources: - Benchmark studies - Performance tests - User reports - Direct measurement

dual-explanation.technical: Performance claims are context-dependent and require understanding of test conditions
dual-explanation.simple: Like verifying car mileage claims by understanding the test conditions used

type.name: Cost Information
type.sources: - Official pricing - Terms of service - Billing documentation - User experiences

dual-explanation.technical: Cost information directly impacts budget planning and requires precise validation
dual-explanation.simple: Like checking the full price including taxes and fees before making a purchase

initial-search.decision-point: If consistent information → Proceed If conflicting → Expand search If no results → Acknowledge uncertainty

expanded-search.triggers: - Conflicting information found - Critical decision point - High-risk change - User specifically requests
expanded-search.strategy: - Vary search terms - Include year filters (2024-2025) - Search academic sources - Check official forums

exhaustive-search.triggers: - Safety-critical information - Legal/compliance issues - Fundamental architecture decisions
exhaustive-search.strategy: - Deep technical documentation - Direct source code review - Expert consultation - Historical analysis

dual-explanation.technical: Adaptive search strategies optimize resource allocation while maintaining validation quality
dual-explanation.simple: Like adjusting how thoroughly you research based on how important the decision is

tier.name: Authoritative
tier.sources: - Official documentation - Source code - Published specifications - Vendor announcements

tier.name: Expert
tier.sources: - Recognized experts - Academic papers - Industry leaders - Core contributors

tier.name: Community
tier.sources: - Stack Overflow (high-voted) - GitHub discussions - Technical blogs - Forum consensus

tier.name: Anecdotal
tier.sources: - Personal blogs - Reddit comments - Unverified claims - Old information (>2 years)

dual-explanation.technical: Source credibility weighting provides consistent reliability assessment across validation tasks
dual-explanation.simple: Like knowing which friends give reliable advice vs. those who guess a lot

dual-explanation.technical: Decision trees provide consistent, repeatable validation workflows with clear decision points
dual-explanation.simple: Like having a flowchart that helps you make the same good decisions every time

checkpoint.name: Pre-Implementation
checkpoint.checks: □ Requirements validated with user □ Technical approach researched □ Dependencies verified □ Risks identified and validated

checkpoint.name: During Implementation
checkpoint.checks: □ Assumptions tested □ Documentation checked □ Behavior verified □ Edge cases validated

checkpoint.name: Post-Implementation
checkpoint.checks: □ All tests passing □ Documentation accurate □ Performance validated □ User requirements met

checkpoint.name: Before Commit
checkpoint.checks: □ Code reviewed □ Tests comprehensive □ Documentation updated □ No unvalidated claims

dual-explanation.technical: Checkpoints provide systematic quality gates throughout the development lifecycle
dual-explanation.simple: Like having safety checks at different points during a project to catch problems early

dual-explanation.technical: Quantitative metrics enable objective validation quality assessment and improvement
dual-explanation.simple: Like keeping score in validation to know if you're getting better at it

pitfall.name: Confirmation Bias
pitfall.description: Only finding sources that agree with assumption

pitfall.name: Single Source Dependency
pitfall.description: Relying on one source, even if authoritative
pitfall.prevention: Always verify with at least 2 more sources

pitfall.name: Assumption Propagation
pitfall.prevention: Validate each link in reasoning chain

dual-explanation.technical: Pitfall awareness prevents systematic validation errors and cognitive biases
dual-explanation.simple: Like knowing the common mistakes people make so you can avoid them

enforcement-rules.mandatory-rules: 1. No claims without validation 2. No validation without documentation 3. No high confidence without multiple sources 4. No implementation without validated approach 5. No commit without validation complete
enforcement-rules.consequences: - Unvalidated claim → Must acknowledge uncertainty - Failed validation → Cannot proceed with change - Incomplete validation → Block until complete - False validation → Immediate correction required

document.quick-validation-checklist:
For every piece of information:
✓ Is this fact or opinion? ✓ Have I searched for verification? ✓ Do I have multiple sources? ✓ Are my sources credible? ✓ Are my sources recent (2024-2025)? ✓ Do sources agree with each other? ✓ Have I noted my confidence level? ✓ Have I provided citations? ✓ Have I acknowledged uncertainty? ✓ Would I stake my reputation on this?
document.core-principles: - Validation protects users from misinformation - Uncertainty is better than false confidence - Every claim needs evidence - When in doubt, research more - User trust depends on our validation
document.final-reminder: Validation is not bureaucracy. It's professionalism. It's the difference between "I think" and "I know." Always validate. Always verify. Always be certain.
